title: Font suggestion for visually impaired
content:
Hello everybody,  
I’m looking for a moden font with superb legibility - it should be made with only that in mind! It’s for a design program for visually impaired people. I’d prefer a sans serif although a serif probably would be better...

Any suggestions will be a great help.

Thanx

Jsbr

comments.content: It’s for paperline and brochures - so it’s mostly text - headers and body.

For a sans, I think you might consider F. Schiavi’s [Sys](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/www.fsd.it/fonts/sys.htm)

(Editing madness Alert !)

Sys is a little bit too “tech” - I’m looking for a more humanistic font.

But thanx anyway ;-)

I won’t elaborate, but Tiresias has its detractors...

I’m thinking any font with suitably open counters, large x-height, and enough differentiation between repeated forms (b/d/p/q), like [Fontin Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/www.josbuivenga.demon.nl/fontinsans.html), would do the job well. More important than the specific choice of the typeface would be how it is set—size, colour, composition...

Thanx a lot for input

Jsbr

This is actually rather dangerous ground, with very little in the way of credible research to back up any suggestions. I’m not sure that research is needed just to select a font for a single publication, though; that’s why you’ve come to the experts.

But first, what kind of visual impairment? Do they just need large type (low acuity), or do they have other disorders?

—  
Joe Clark  
 [http://joeclark.org/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/joeclark.org/ "http://joeclark.org/")

Joe is right, this is dangerous ground, so anything we contribute will be anecdotal and without scientific foundation.

With that in mind, if a font is legible for text setting at 10pt, then making it larger should be okay. Line-length and leading will likely be the gotchas. Assuming the same viewing distance as an unimpaired reader, you’d put less words on a line. As for leading?

Apart from that the other common sense answer might be to use signage fonts – so your open, humanist sans, might be a good approach. But I’d be nervous about these in text settings – for short passages and headings you should be okay.

One can question the Tiresias fonts in general, but their big problem is that all the italics are utterly unusable.

Hmmm, more good blog fodder.

T

<cite>I’m thinking any font with suitably open counters, large x-height, and enough differentiation between repeated forms (b/d/p/q), like Fontin Sans, would do the job well.</cite>

Thanks for mentioning Fontin Sans, Jongseong. I’ve heard even more people say (without me asking :-) that [Delicious](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/www.josbuivenga.demon.nl/delicious.html) does a great job for people who are visual impaired. Maybe Jesper can give it a test run.

[Sassoon](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/www.clubtype.co.uk/fonts/sas/sassoonfonts.html) might also be worth looking at. You can download a [PDF here](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907012101/http:/www.clubtype.co.uk/fonts/sas/Why%20Sassoon.pdf). Although it’s meant for children, it’s designed so that the characters are easily recognizable and distinguishable from each other. In that sense it might also work for people with some form of visual impairment. There are also different versions.
